FacilityName: MFA Anhydrous Ammonia Plant - New Cambria

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary



Facility:   MFA Anhydrous Ammonia Plant

Location:   29400 Colony Ave., New Cambria, MO 

Contact:    Jeremy Teter

Phone:         660-226-5218





1. The Facility Policy



    MFA Incorporated and the employees of the MFA Anhydrous Ammonia Plant in New Cambria are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the New Cambria Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information



    The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient.



3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.



    The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law, and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". The facility will work to meet newest codes as time and budgets allow.



4. The Five-year Accident History



    There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past 5 years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.





5. The Emergency Response Program.



    The facility has;



    a. A written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA

       Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;



    b. Provided State and Local authorities with the emergency

       planning and community right-to-know information as

       required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);



    c. Employees will not respond to any releases

other than to

           activate an emergency shut-off valve while evacuating the

           facility if it is safe for them to do so. Local emergency

           responders will be notified to control any release.



6. Planned changes to improve safety.



    Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safety conditions. Currently the facility is evaluating the requirements of CGA 2.1, 2014 and Process Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and will make the required upgrades needed.







    12/26/12
